p: 9. Time accounts for the intelligibility of being. In § 4 we mentioned that ex-sistence’s ontic structure entails a pretheoretical understanding of being. Our aim is to show that we always, if implicitly, understand being in terms of time. Working from temporality as the being of ex-sistence, SZ I.3 will demonstrate conceptually that time is the horizon or field for understanding and interpreting being.n

To do this we first have to distinguish our understanding of time from the traditional notions of time stretching from Aristotle to Bergson. We will show [cf. SZ I.2. chapter 6] that the traditional notion of time originates from exsistential temporality—as against Bergson’s thesis that time in the traditional sense is actually space.
